DIV1.P: THE DOCTOR AND THE APOTHECARY. A MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT IN TWO ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR C. DILLY, IN THE POULTRY. MDCCLXXXVIII.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: [The lines with inverted commas are omitted in the representation.]

DIV2.STAGE: The outside of Thomaso's house—a view of distant hills, with the sun setting behind them.
STURMWALD, GUZMAN, ANNA, ISABELLA, and THERESA.

LG.HEAD: TRIO.
LG.L: NOW the sun so faintly glancing▪
O'er the western hills his ray;

LG.HEAD: TRIO.
LG.L: To her power due homage pay.
Mirth, to dance and song inviting,
Bids us hail the close of day.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: What moping yet, my friend Guz∣man?—For shame, you a sailor, and carry sor∣row aboard! Zounds, if I had lost a mistress—nay, had it been my wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Well, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I think I cou'd have comforted my∣self. Ah Captain, how far preferable are the charms of peace, and a country life, to all the bustle and danger of a campaign!

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: It may be so to you, Signor Tho∣maso, who slumber in the inglorious lap of peace—but war is my element; glory is my mistress; and I have courted her amid the cannon's thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Many men of many minds, Captain; for my part, I always prefered a more quiet kind of courtship; but i'faith you are a man of true gallantry to remain so partial to your mistress, after having lost the use of a leg and an eye in her service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P:
A leg and an eye! Psha—tri∣fles! while my honour, a soldier's vital spark,
has escap'd unhurt.—You may be a very good apothecary, Signor Thomaso, and may under∣stand lotions and potions—but as to a soldier's honor—

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Ah, very true, Captain. He is a most provoking man, tho' he is my husband. For shame, after our good friend, Captain Sturmwald, has come all the way from Ger∣many to marry our daughter Anna.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Nay, I'm sure, the Captain knows, I mean no harm.—Anna, come hi∣ther, child (aside to Anna.) Why don't you smile upon your husband that is to be?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Do not, my dear father, persist in this cruel solicitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Psha! how can you be so obstinate!—though the Captain is not very handsome, he is very rich. 'Tis true, he is rather old; but then you know you have the better chance of being a widow soon; and as to his having but one eye, it ought to be his recom∣mendation, for you'll have no trouble in disco∣vering his blind side.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Lookee Anna—you know my way of arguing, and so does your father. It is my pleasure that you marry Captain Sturmwald▪ and have him you shall!

SP.SPEAKER: Guzman.
SP.P: Have a little patience with her, my dear madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Then you are resoved to render me mi∣serable.

LG.L: ON Love's blest altar burns the flame
Whence Hymen's torch should kindle bright,
To bliss which boasts fair Virtue's name,
It casts its pure and radiant light.
The prospect which their light bestows,

DIV2.STAGE: (Exeunt Anna, Isabella, and Guzman, into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Anna's reluctance is certainly owing to that impertinent slut, her cousin. I'm sure she doet not inherit her obstinacy from me. When my mother proposed a husband to me, I gave my consent without a moment's hesitation. Didn't I, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: True, my love; but then I had not lost any of my limbs in pursuit of glory, like the Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: I was thinking whether I had not better talk to the young lady myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: To be sure—how the deuce else are you to gain her consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: I'faith I will. She'll find me very entertaining.—I'll breakfast with her to-mor∣row, and give her the history of my last cam∣paign. I'll come early in the morning, that I may finish the story before dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Well, Captain, now my wife is gone, I want to have a little talk with you about my new invented miraculous drops, as I call them, that cure all disorders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Do they cure gun-shot wounds?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: I wish then I had had a bottle in that engagement where I was wounded by a French dragoon in the shoulder—I'll tell you how it happen'd:

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Unfortunate man that I am! He'll talk like my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: We were fording a river, and I was about the middle of the stream—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: He won't be out of the wa∣ter this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Strumwald.
SP.P: A scoundrel French dragoon, upon a black horse—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso▪
SP.P: A grey horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Black—black as jet.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P:
I beg your pardon, Captain, it was a grey horse. I have heard you tell the story
twenty times, and you always said the horse was grey.—So much for that.—Now you must know my drops—

SP.SPEAKER: Strumwald.
SP.P: You have heard me tell the story then?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Often.—So my drops—

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: And what d'ye think of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: One of the best stories I ever heard in my life.—So—

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: I'm very glad you like it. I'll tell you another.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Curse his stories. (Aside.) To-mor∣row, Captain, I shall be happy to hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Strumwald.
SP.P: Well, if you are tir'd of my com∣pany, I'll go and get a bottle of good wine, to make me sleep soundly; and so adieu, my dear father-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Adieu, my dear son-in-law. (Aside.) What a cursed bore he is for talking!

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: A good kind of a man enough; but can't bear to hear any body talk except him∣self.

DIV2.STAGE: The sun sets, and Thomaso's shop is lighted up.

LG.HEAD: AIR. CARLOS.
LG.L: WHEN wilt thou cease, thou pleasing pain,
With cruel sway to rend my heart?
Yet tho' of torment I complain,
Alas! I fear to cure the smart.

LG.HEAD: AIR. JUAN.
LG.L: I'll tell you what is better far:
Call good humour to your aid,
And play the lass a tune upon the sweet guittar.
If a heart has nature dealt her,
Music's charms will surely melt her;
But shou'd the gipsey answer, No,
Sing tol de rol, and let her go.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Zounds! I see some one at the door. A rival perhaps!
SP.STAGE: (They approach, each with his hand on his sword, till Carlos perceives it to be Juan.)
SP.P: Juan!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Carlos! my dear boy, how d'ye do?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: I'm heartily glad to see you—no, i'faith, now I think again, I am not glad to see you, till I know what brought you hither!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: I was going to tell you, I have an ap∣pointment with a very pretty girl in this house—

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Ah! my fears.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: So I am sure you will be complaisant enough to wish me a good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Faith I am sorry to deny you. But I happen to have an assignation here myself. You perceive a light in that window?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: That light is my signal.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Egad 'tis my signal too! So I'm sure you will be complaisant enough to wish me a good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Sir, this insult—

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Insult, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Though, now I recollect myself, per∣haps we are going to cut throats, without any cause. There are two fair damsels in that house. What is the name of your mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Anna, the daughter of old Thomaso, the Apothecary;—and your mistress is—

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Isabella! her laughing little cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P:
Then I am glad to see you, after all—and yet I am an unlucky dog, Juan. They are going to marry my dear Anna, to old Sturm∣wald, the German Captain. I dare not acquaint my father of my passion for her; you know he and Thomaso are the bitterest enemies. The
only resource left is, to carry her off; and I have, for this week past, in vain sought an op∣portunity of seeing her.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Oh, the devil!—old Thomaso's man to shut the shop up. Stand aside—
SP.STAGE: (Thomaso's man shuts up the shop, while they talk aside.)
SP.P: Give me your hand, Carlos—you shall see Anna; speak to her, and carry her off this night.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: My dear Juan, how is this to be ac∣complished?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: The first thing is to get the old fellow out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: And how is that to be manag'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Very easily—as thus: I'll act an old woman, and bring him down I'll warrant you. (Knocks.) Say nothing, and stand aside.

DIV2.STAGE: (Thomaso opens the window and looks out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: What the devil is all that noise for?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Pray, is this Signor Thomaso's?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Why, what do you want with Signor Thomaso, good woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: The sick gentleman, Signor, at the next inn, is much worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P:
I'm sorry for it—I wish the gentle∣man had been much worse an hour ago; be∣cause
then I cou'd have attended him—but at present I'm going to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Dear Signor, you won't leave the poor man to the mercy of an ignorant physician?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Why, who attends him?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Dr. Bilioso.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Then I give him over. Good night to you good woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Our plot is ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Not yet, Carlos.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Zounds! what's the matter with the woman? Go about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: The sick man has heard wonders related of your famous drops, Signor.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Eh! what!—Oh! ho! he has heard of my drops. Well, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: And he wishes you would come to him directly, and bring a bottle in your pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Aye, that I will—poor soul! poor soul!—I'll cure him in spite of his Physician. (Calls within.) Hallo! Pedro! (To Juan.) I'll go with you, good woman, and as we walk, I'll tell you some of the cures I have performed.—I'll wait on you instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: This is a prosperous beginning, Juan.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Hush, not a word—we must retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: And so, good woman, you say—Hey day, she is gone! The poor gentleman's case is urgent, I suppose—so I'll lose no time. What a pleasure it is to attend sensible patients! I dare say he is a shrewd fellow, by his wishing to try my drops.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! The old fox is fairly unkennel'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: But how are we to get into the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: The door is fast.—Eh! i'faith this shut∣ter is unbolted, (opens part of the shutter) so we will e'en get in at the shop window.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: My best friend!

DIV2.STAGE: (Going to climb in at the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan▪
SP.P: Hold! let me reconnoitre first. I know every part of the house—follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Kind Cupid light us on our way.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Psha! Zounds! a lantern would light us much better. So rot your heroics, and follow me.

DIV2.STAGE: (Gets in at the window, and Carlos follows.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P:
Tol de rol, de rol—halt!—Stand to your arms, Captain Sturmwald. Do my eyes
deceive me, or have the enemy besieged my fa∣ther-in-law's house, and made a practicable breach in the shop window? Who the devil are they?—Thieves! No, i'faith, that can't be.—Who'd think of stealing any thing out of an Apothecary's shop? Perhaps they are gallants—have at you, my boys;—I must enter and de∣fend my father-in-law. (Going to climb in at the window, he stops) but hold! a prudent general should know what force he has to contend with—besides, I forget,—old Bolus is not at home—I remember I met him just now—Egad I'll go and fetch him, and we'll surprize the enemy to∣gether. How lucky it is that I am sober. If I had taken the other bottle, my senses might have been confus'd; but now I am cool and col∣lected. Ah! there is nothing like drinking in moderation.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, the Inside of Thomaso's Shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Hush! tread softly, for your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Why, what are you afraid of?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: If Thomaso should return! and then perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Perhaps what? Why, your whole con∣versation is composed of Ifs—Buts—Perhapses—and Supposes—a mere vocabulary of doubts.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Hark! I hear Anna's voice—the sound transports me. Oh, Juan, I scarcely know where I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan▪
SP.P: Why, then I'll tell you—This is an apothecary's shop; it is dark, and you are sur∣rounded with phials, therefore take care you break none—Those are stairs before us, and lead to the room where our dear girls are—I shall go up first, and you may follow, unless you prefer staying here—I have now given you full informa∣tion, and so come along.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a room in Thomaso's house. The moon is seen through a window.

LG.L: Of vows so sweet, yet broken,

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Isabella, 'tis a whole week since I saw my Carlos; how can he say he loves me, and yet suffer them to marry me to this hateful Ger∣man officer?

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Anna, why don't you go to your chamber, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Heavens! your mother is not gone to bed yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: And do you think my Carlos has really forsaken me? My Carlos, did I say—Yes, will repeat it—My heart yields to the fond elu¦sion of my tongue, and I think I love him better every time I call him mine.

SP.SPEAKER: ISABELLA sola.
SP.P: Poor Anna; I love her sincerely, and yet I am not sorry she is gone—I think Juan must be here soon—and—and perhaps our conversation would be very uninteresting to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Oh, Isabella, I'm frightened out of my wits. Two men have got into the house, and I think it is your lover and mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Well, my dear, and what is there so alarming in all that?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: My dear Anna!

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: My dear Isabella!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Hush! you'll wake your mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Anna! What's the matter, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: My cousin was frighten'd at some∣thing, but I am sure there was no reason to be afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Do you know, Isabella, this unreason∣able creature has brought me a marriage con∣tract, and would have me seize this moment to elope with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: And do you know, Ma∣dam, this unreasonable creature hesitates, though she promised me long ago to elope, whenever I could find an opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Psha! Marry first, and dispute after∣wards; that would be much more in the common order of things.—Come, my dear Isabella, let us set them a good example;—leave dissimulation to knaves and coquettes, and lead up the dance of Hymen as first couple—

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Why, if I were sure you wou'd never wish to change partners.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Consider, my dear Anna, the moments fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: I vow, your mother is not in bed yet— (To Anna.) Away! away instantly, and leave me to keep her quiet—I'll follow you directly. (Exeunt Anna, Carlos, and Juan.) I'll sing, that she may suspect nothing.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Ye hours that part my love and me,
The dawn of bliss obscur'd by clouds
Of doubt, in vain ye keep.
Still I through Sorrow's tedious night,
On that I fix my anxious eye

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Hey! Guzman! Pedro! where the devil are ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Oh, Isabella, my father is come home; all the doors are lock'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: And our retreat cut off.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Then we are all lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: No, faith, I'm afraid we are all found. Where can we hide ourselves?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Go into our chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: My father is now at the chamber door.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: In here then.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: That's my mother's room.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: We are in luck—My uncle, in his hurry to visit his patient, has left the door of his study open—In—In—directly. (Exit Carlos, and Juan into the closet.) Here comes your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Anna! Theresa! Isabella! there are thieves in the house!

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Thieves! bless me, Sir, what shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Take 'em, to be sure—Take 'em, dead or alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: What's that you say—Thieves in our house?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: The Captain saw them get in.—He'll tell you the whole story.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: That I will, with a great deal of pleasure. As I was coming from the tavern, where I had been drinking a glass in moderation, as sober as I am now—I saw two men getting into my father-in-law's house.—What's to be done, thought I—For this was enough to stagger me, you may suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Oh! certainly, (Aside) that you had enough to stagger you, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Yes, and here is enough to stagger us all—This paper explains to me, that these thieves are of Cupid's gang; gentlemen who commit sentimen∣tal robberies on the hearts of young ladies.—There, Thomaso, read that!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: What do I see! a contract of mar∣riage, between my daughter and Carlos!

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Carlos! What the devil! the ene∣my surprize us in our own camp—Egad, we'll hold a council of war immediately; I have some∣thing in my head—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Yes, rather more than you ought to have.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: I tell you, I am sure young Carlos is in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Is he? Why then we'll break up the council.—Bella! horrida bella! is our resolve; and so let us search for the enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Bless me, Captain Sturmwald—do you know that is my chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Well, my dear mother-in-law—and is not a lady's chamber the most likely place to find a man of gallantry? However, I'll wheel to the right about, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Stop, Captain; no person ever enters that closet but myself—'Tis here where I com∣pose my miraculous drops.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Aye, aye, I understand you—'Tis your hocus pocus shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: No, Sir, 'tis my miracle shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Your magazine for the destruc∣tive ammunition of physic.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: My laboratory for the arcana of the Materia Medica. 'Tis the Temple of Health; and the rosy Goddess herself presides over my pestle and mortar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: A small room for the Temple of Health, I think, and rather dark—Suppose, father-in-law, instead of confining the poor Goddess of Health to her room, you were to let her visit some of your patients.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: You may sneer as you please, Captain Sturmwald; I have the key of that closet in my pocket, and there it shall remain—So let us finish a foolish adventure, by wishing each other a good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: I shall take you with me, young ladies, to prevent further accidents. Captain Sturm∣wald, where will you sleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: No where, Madam—I suspect the enemy is in ambuscade. I will be the centinel of the night—Rest securely, while I guard you—Here I take my post, and shall be on the watch, in case the enemy shou'd make a sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Well, Captain, I have no objection—Here is the key of the house, in case you chuse to refresh yourself with a walk in the morn∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: ANNA, ISABELLA, THERESA, STURMWALD, and GUZMAN.
SP.L: But see the moon ascending high,
Reigns the empress of the sky;
And i the zenith of her power,

SP.SPEAKER: THERESA.
SP.L: Yes, Miss, so must you—(to Isabella)

DIV2.STAGE: (Exeunt Thomaso and Guzman, at the door in the middle of the scene, and Sturmwald places himself on a couch, before Thomaso's closet door.

LG.HEAD: AIR. STURMWALD.
LG.L: " Come on, my boys, now I'm commander,
" Tho' you're as brave as Alexander.
" On my guard here am I.
" I fear no ambush, no entrapping,
" No one shall catch old Sturmwald napping."

DIV2.STAGE: Juan and Carlos come out of the closet.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Softly, softly—First let us secure the key of the shop door, to let ourselves out.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: That this old remnant of mortality shou'd think of rivalling a young fellow, with his five senses in perfection!

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: But to our plot, good Juan—our plot—We have no time to lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Faith, that's very true—So in you must go, my old commander.

DIV2.STAGE: (They wheel the couch into Thomaso's closet.

LG.L: Bacchus now his nap is taking;
But his pow'r can ne'er subdue
Hold the cup with bended knee;
None but fools, his worth o'er-rating,
With the servant make too free.

DIV2.STAGE: (Juan comes out of the closet, and brings with him Sturmwald's cloak, hat, and patch.

LG.HEAD: DUET. CARLOS and JUAN.
LG.L: Bacchus now his nap is taking;
But his pow'r can ne'er subdue

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE. The outside of Dr. Bilioso's house.

SP.SPEAKER: GUZMAN.
SP.P: BUT pray, Perez, is Doctor Bilioso inform'd of his son's attachment to my cousin, Anna?

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: Oh dear, no. My old master hates Signor Thomaso to that degree, that he would ra∣ther see his son hanged than married into the fa∣mily.

SP.SPEAKER: Guzman.
SP.P: Though unacquainted with poor Carlos, I sympathize with him—had my Leonora lived—

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: Ah! but she is gone—and your honour has been doleful and dumpish, as one may say, ever since you came home from sea! Oh! I love to hear you talk of old stories—you make me so melancholy, and so happy, that I cry by the hour together.

SP.SPEAKER: Guzman.
SP.P: Poor fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: And pray good Signor Guzman, when you was voyaging about on the stormy main, and fighting the Algerines, was not you now and then frightened too much to think of your love?

SP.SPEAKER: Guzman.
SP.P: No, Perez.—True love purifies the soul from every base alloy.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: LET angry Ocean to the sky,
In proud despite his billows roll;
Let thunders to his threats reply,
Fear is a stranger to my soul.
Within the heart which love illumes,
And blesses with his sacred rays,
It fades before the hallow'd blaze.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Tho' War with sullen aspect low'r,
And crimson o'er the troubled wave,
The dangers of the fight I brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: Here comes my master—and as cross as usual.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P:
What a cursed neighbourhood is this for a physician to live in. No such thing as an asthma, or a fit of the gout, to be met with from year's end to year's end. All the villagers are such a set of d—n'd vulgar, healthy dogs—never have the pleasure of seeing a meagre, bi∣lious,
gentleman-like man within ten miles of the place.—How comfortable it would be to live at Constantinople, where the plague rages all the year.—And then people laugh more here, than in all Spain besides.—Ah! I don't like laughing. Well, Perez—any body ill this morn∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: No, Sir—all well.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Aye—and will remain so as long as this plaguy fine weather lasts—no chance of another influenza.—I, who am the physician, am the only sick man in the parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: Yes, your worship seems stuck up here by way of a medical scarecrow, to frighten away sickness.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Or rather like an electrical con∣ductor—I save the neighbourhood from danger, by attracting it to myself.—Ah! I lost the only good patient I had, in my friend Alvarez—as fine a corpulent—inactive subject as a physician would wish for. What with repletion, and want of exercise, the good soul was always ailing. I had great expectations from him—but he grew stingy as he grew rich—avarice produced abstinence, and he starved away the only hopes I had left.

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: There's the traveller who was taken ill at the next inn—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Aye, the only person I have at present under my care, and he is a foreigner—no native would have behaved so civilly as to be taken ill—Not got well, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: Yes, so they say—the apothecary, Tho∣maso, was sent for to him last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: What! send for my enemy—my antagonist, Thomaso, the apothecary? A man of honour wou'd have sooner died under his physi∣cian's hands, than have played him such a trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: And he took some of Thomaso's quack medicine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: O curse his quack medicine—I hate all violent remedies—they make an end of a business so soon;—they either kill or cure; and then either way one loses the patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Perez.
SP.P: And so Thomaso—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Oh rot him—I'll go to the ras∣cally quack directly; my patients are my pro∣perty—and shall I tamely suffer my property to be taken from me? I'll trounce the dog. No, no, if a Doctor's patients are permitted to slip through his fingers, and get well by stealth, there's an end to all law and justice.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE. A room in Thomaso's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Ah ha! the Captain off already—I did'n't expect he had shaken off the effects of last night's dose quite so soon. I can hardly re∣concile it to myself to sacrifice poor Anna to such a sot. My conscience revolts against it, and whispers—Aye: but then my wife talks so much louder than my conscience; and so there's an end of the matter.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter JUAN (behind) disguised as STURMWALD, and CARLOS disguised as a Notary, who listens at the corner of the scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Father-in-law, good morning to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Eh! what! bless my soul, son-in-law, how do ye do? There seems to be a won∣derful change in your voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: All the effects of last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I suppose so—a violent cold no doubt—my drops are remarkably good for the voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: No, no, never mind—I'll tell you a story—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I'd rather you'd let it alone.—Come now—one spoonful will be enough.—'Tis a most wonderful remedy—I have it here in this closet.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Curse your drops.—I am sure the lo∣vers of your daughter and niece are now in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Well, Captain, perhaps you know best—but upon my soul I don't believe a word of the matter. Now let me fetch a bottle of drops.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: My jealousy is alarm'd, Sir—and I must be your son-in-law this morning, or not at all—No reply! I have brought this gentleman with me; he is my notary, and has drawn up a marriage contract. So call your wife and the bride; let us sign and seal, and then to church immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Well, but Captain—

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: I'm commanding officer to-day. So no more words, father-in-law. (Exit Thomaso.) Ha! ha! ha! Well Carlos, how have I imitated the old German Captain?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: —To a miracle. I wish I may play my part half as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P:
Psha! what difficulty is there in it—te old folks will take you for the notary who hs prepared the contract of marriage between Ana and Sturmwald; instead of that you will
substitute the other contract, in which your own name is inserted. But here they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: No, nothing shall shake my constancy—every obstacle you raise, serves but to increase my affection.

LG.HEAD: AIR. ANNA.
LG.L: The breath of doubt and fear,

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Well Signor Thomaso, have you looke over the contract?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I have; and find it perfectly rigt.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Very well; but where's Isabella?

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Oh, I'll call her.—Isabella!—but I assure you I would not trust her with any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: My dear Juan, what means—

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Hush, my love—ask no questions—persuade Anna to sign that paper—it is a contract of marriage between her and Carlos, who you see personates the notary.

DIV2.STAGE: (Carlos offers the contract to Anna, who puts it aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: No, nothing shall induce me to sign this hated paper. Oh Carlos, why are you not here to snatch me from impending ruin!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Daughter, do not oblige me to exert my authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Let her beware of my authority, which is much greater.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Psha, psha! persuasion is better than authority.—Let her cousin talk to her. (Isa∣bella whispers Anna.) These girls know the way to each others hearts; there—mother-in▪law, you see, she hangs out a smile of truce already.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: My dear daughter, you transport me.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Come sign your consent to the marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Sign it—aye, that I will—Come hus∣band—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Egad, Captain, I don't understand that notary's whispering my daughter, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: 'Tis his way—come sign your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: No Sir— (to Carlos.)—I insist upon knowing what you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: What I mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: If you put him in a passion, take care of yourself; he is the most choleric fellow—you had better sign at once.

LG.HEAD: AIR. CARLOS.
LG.L: Zounds, Sir, my character none shall accuse!
Behold this artifice, true love devising,
Your Carlos thus to all but you disguising;
My only chance, I see, is pique pretending;
On that alone success is now depending.
Kind fortune see, at length, our prayers heeding,
Relenting, gives us promise of succeeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Come, come, now all's finish'd, let us away to church.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Well, I'll be with you in a mo∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, Juan, let us be gone. If Sturmwald should wake, we are ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: I beg your pardon for de∣taining you.—Mr. Notary, conduct these la∣dies to my house, and I'll follow you immedi∣ately.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Stop! stay—What! without my wife's leave!

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Halloo! death and fury! where am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Eh! what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Thieves! thieves!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I'm lost in amazement.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Did not I tell you one of the rogues was hid there?—I'll run and fetch an Alguazil.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: You run.—Why, you forget you are lame.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Egad so I do—but I am so interested in this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: And you have recover'd your voice too.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: No, faith, I think I'm as hoarse as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Thomaso! Signor Thomaso!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: 'Tis the Captain's voice. Egad I'll fetch an Alguazil myself, and make sure of one of ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Signor Thomaso!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Have a little patience. (Aside.) What's to be done! If I attempt the door, I meet the Alguazil. I must e'en try this chamber-win∣dow.

DIV2.STAGE: Pulls off Sturmwald's hat, cloak, and patch; throws 'em down at the closet-door, and then goes into Theresa's chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: An Alguazil will be here presently, and then, Mr. Scoundrel.— (Sees the cloak and patch.) Hey dey! what's all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Will nobody hear me!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: It is Sturmwald! Oh, my mind misgives me.

DIV2.STAGE: (He hears the noise of phials breaking in the closet, and rushes in.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: All my phials of drops broken! Let me tell you, Captain Sturmwald—

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Zounds! Sir, you shall tell me no∣thing but what I desire to know. I say, Sir, how did I come in that closet?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: That's the very question I want to ask you; and, if we both ask the same question, how the devil are we to get an answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Why, you dirty scrap of an Apo∣thecary, how dare you laugh at me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I laugh! Look at the bottles you've broke—I believe I shall never laugh again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: You are all in the plot—'tis a trick to abuse me; but I'll be reveng'd. S'blood and thunder! to make a jest of me, who have fought in sixteen different battles! Did you know that?—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Yes, you have often told me the names of them all. But do hear me, Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: I'll hear nothing but revenge.—To cram me up in a dark closet, among pickled snakes, and stuffed alligators; me, who have liv'd amidst fire and smoke, who have fought for every Prince in Europe by turns, and always had the honour to be wounded! Who, to this hour, bear the trophies of war in every limb, and rejoice in the aches, the cramps, and the twinges of glory!

DIV2.STAGE: THERESA enters, and THOMASO explains to her, in dumb shew, what has passed.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: I am sure, Captain, I don't wonder at your being angry with my husband—he's a poor blundering creature, as I often tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Nay, the Captain knows I never mean to offend him. I've done all I can—

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Psha! so you always say. Go, get an Alguazil, and seek for the rogues that have stolen our two girls, do. (Exit Thomaso.) Come, Cap∣tain, suppose you and I follow him. For my sake be patient.—The brave never refuse the re∣quests of the fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Never; and to prove it, I'll tell you a story of what happen'd when I was in Germany.

DIV2.STAGE: JUAN comes softly out of THERESA'S room in wo∣men's clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: This confounded window is too closely barr'd even for a mouse to creep through. How∣ever, in this disguise, I think I shall get off un∣discovered;—or, if I should be questioned, I'll pass for a patient, come to ask Thomaso's ad∣vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.STAGE: (speaking to a servant as he comes on.)
SP.P: Don't tell me—I say he is at home, and I will see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Who comes here?—Dr. Bilioso him∣self!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: But I beg pardon; you want ad∣vice, I presume;—let me feel your pulse.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Zounds! I shall be disco∣vered. (Aside.) Dear Sir, pray let me alone—my nerves are so weak—and you agitate me so.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Why, really Madam, you have rather agitated me. I think I never yet met with a Lady so strong in the arm. Pray, what is your complaint, Ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: My complaint is against Thomaso, who has killed a poor friend of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Oh, he has done worse than that—he has taken a patient away from me, after I had given him over. So if he recovers the man, he ruins my reputation.—There's an unfeeling scoundrel, for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Ah, you and I mean the same person—the poor gentleman at the next inn.—But Tho∣maso's drops have done for him—my poor friend is no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: I'm heartily glad of it—very sorry for it, I mean. I thank you for the news, how∣ever. Now I have that rogue, Thomaso, in my gripe.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Lose no time, Sir, but get an officer immediately, and secure Thomaso.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: That I will.—Aye, aye—

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Surely, Sir, you will have the gallantry to conduct me safe out of this house.—If I should be insulted!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Insulted! Lord, Ma'am, there's no danger of that. Nature has furnish'd you with such powers of defence; united the charms of your sex, to the strength of ours. You are a glass of Nature's choicest cordial, Madam; sweet and strong at the same time.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to a Wood, with a Village seen at a distance through the Trees.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Consider, my dear Anna, we have your father's signature to our contract of marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: But will he give his voluntary consent, to what has been procur'd by artifice?

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Fear nothing, my dear; trust to me.

LG.HEAD: AIR. CARLOS.
LG.L: AM I belov'd? Can you refuse?
Alas! my heart for pity sues.
That heart whose constancy you've known;
That heart you've fondly call'd your own.
Warns us where our danger lies.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Well, Isabella, any news of Juan?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Alas! none—Every human being that passed at a distance, did my pliant fancy conjure up into a likeness of Juan.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: The rising ground, on the left hand, commands a prospect of the road—Let me try, whether friendship may not see more clearly than love.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Are not we a couple of wild girls, Isa∣bella?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Not incorrigible, my dear cousin, how∣ever; we have pursued a very effectual mode of taming ourselves, by getting married.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: To be sure, we have utter'd the fatal, Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P:
The fatal, Yes. Why, my dear, do you think our lovers are such fools, as to think
the better, or the worse of our affection for them, because we have said, Yes.

LG.HEAD: AIR. ISABELLA.
LG.L: Who on words builds hopes of bliss!
And fondly thinks we love discover,
When the tongue, the heart belying,
Ah! how vain is art's profession,
While the eyes betray the fiction,
And the cheeks with blushes glow,
And the tongue still faulters, No.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: Here is Juan—So all we have to do, is to mount our horses and gallop off.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Hold! you're mistaken—You've some∣thing else to do, I assure you. We have cer∣tainly been traced from the village—Doctor Bi∣lioso, and Signor Thomaso, are both coming up the hill, different ways, and will most likely meet at this spot.—But they are here.

DIV2.STAGE: (Anna, Isabella, Carlos, and Juan, retire up the stage.
Enter Dr. BILIOSO and THOMASO, meeting—Each with an Alguazil.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Oh! you vile quack! Where's my patient?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Where is my daughter, you old rogue—You have assisted your son to run away with her—Lay hold of him, Alguazil.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: What! Why, I brought an officer to seize you. Here, do your duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Dear gentlemen, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Why, Sir, that fellow is a quack, and has killed one of my patients.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: That's impossible; for though he calls himself a physician, he has no patients to kill.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: What! Do you forget the poor gentleman at the inn?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Well, he was fair game—You had given him over.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Zounds, Sir, what does that signi∣fy—I have given over fifty people in my time, who have recovered afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: My plot has taken, I perceive—they believe him dead yet.— (To Thomaso.) I'faith, this is a serious affair. You had better com∣pound this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: He won't agree to it—He hates me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Let me talk to him. (Aside to Dr. Bilioso.) Sir, when I see so valuable a life as your's in danger—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: My life in danger!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: From that bloody minded apothecary—I find, your son has cloped with his daughter, and he is resolved to be revenged, by assassinating you and your whole family. See, how he looks at you!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: Ratsbane and arsenic in his coun∣tenance!

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Did you ever see such a determin'd dog. He is resolved to hang you!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: I dare say he has the rope in his pocket. Pray, mollify him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Bilioso.
SP.P: I'faith, I don't half like him—Tell him, I'll forgive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Dismiss your Alguazils. (Exit Alguazils.) You bind yourselves to stand by my determina∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. and Thomaso.
SP.P: We do.

SP.SPEAKER: Juan.
SP.P: Then, I believe, all parties are satisfied. Appear, appear!

DIV2.STAGE: ANNA, CARLOS, and ISABELLA, come forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: My dear father!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Zounds, what is all this!

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: A general muster of the whole corps, egad; deserters and all. You are my prisoner, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Carlos.
SP.P: No, Sir, not while I can defend her.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! hear me—the brave are ever generous; do not attempt a life so dear to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P: Bullets and gunpowder! why don't you love me then—I thought you told me, mother-in-law, it was all maiden coyness in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: Stuff and nonsense—Take her, Cap∣tain Sturmwald, she is your's—Defend your ho∣nour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sturmwald.
SP.P:
And that my honor may be worth defending, I'll take care it shall not be tarnished
by an unjust action.—Anna, your mother says you are mine.—If so, I dispose of what is mine—thus:— (giving her hand to Carlos.) Come, come, we have by mistake opposed the union of hearts on their march to form a junction, and we are defeated. So much the better—who wou'd wish to conquer in a bad cause? You must consent to unite these turtles.

SP.SPEAKER: Thoamso.
SP.P: Has my wife any objection?

SP.SPEAKER: Theresa.
SP.P: I'll have nothing to do with it—so act as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomaso.
SP.P: Why then give me your hand, Doc∣tor (to Dr. Bilioso) and here's an end of old quarrels.—Take my daughter, young man, (to Carlos) and you take my niece (to Juan); and you (to Sturmwald) take my wife if you will▪ Egad, I am in such a good humour, I cou'd give away any thing.

LG.HEAD: FINALE.
LG.L: Of love we sing the gentle sway!
When youth shall be no more.
